乱港头目认罪，反华机构要撤出香港∣香港一日
translation:
Eight "12 Fugitives" remanded in custody for obstruction of justice
Nine of the 12 fugitives who were convicted of illegally crossing the border in the Mainland last year were charged with obstructing justice after returning to Hong Kong. Except for the 17-year-old defendant Huang Linfu, who has been sentenced to a training center, the other eight people were arraigned in the District Court today (26th). The defense stated that it needed time to obtain instructions from the defendant and discuss it with the prosecution. The judge therefore adjourned the case to December 21 for another hearing, and the eight defendants were remanded in custody.
The eight defendants are Liao Ziwen (18 years old, unemployed), Zheng Zihao (19 years old, technician), Zhang Junfu (24 years old, student), Zhang Mingyu (21 years old, transport worker), Yan Wenqian (22 years old, student), Huang Weiran (30 years old) , unemployed), Li Zixian (31 years old, surveyor) and Guo Zilin (19 years old, student).
The charges allege that between December 2019 and August 23, 2020, they, together with several people, committed one or a series of acts that tended to obstruct justice in Hong Kong, that is, by causing Liu Ziwen, Zheng Zihao, Zhang Junfu, Zhang Mingyu, Yan Wenqian, Huang Linfu, Huang Weiyan, Li Zixian, Guo Zilin, Qiao Yingyu, Tang Xianran and Li Yuxuan fled the jurisdiction of Hong Kong to prevent and hinder the investigation of the Hong Kong Police Force and any criminal proceedings arising out of or likely to arise out of the investigation. .

香港立法会主席严厉谴责示威者再次冲击立法会大楼
translation: According to Hong Kong media reports, Legislative Council Chairman Leung Kwan-yin said through his spokesman that he was extremely saddened and disappointed that demonstrators once again attacked the Legislative Council building. He severely condemned the demonstrators for disregarding the safety of those present and throwing flammable objects and bricks.

title: Opinion | Hong Kong’s downfall is a warning to the world  - The Washington Post
AP PHOTOS: The rise and fall of Hong Kong's July 1 protests | AP News
香港修例风波回望：当青年被绑上暴力战车
translation:
Black hands, “stars” and “cannon fodder”
In October 2014, a Hong Kong youth under the age of 20 appeared on the cover of Time magazine in the United States, with the article "The Face of Resistance." Since then, the life of "Hong Kong independence" activist Joshua Wong seems to have entered a "highlight moment" and he has been built into a "political star".
During the turmoil over the amendment bill that began in June 2019, Huang Zhifeng and other "star-level" figures who became the "vanguard" of anti-China chaos in Hong Kong, including Shum Zijie, Liu Yongkuang, Chen Haotian, Au Noxuan... were seen in the media's cameras and In front of the microphone, they incited and incited at the top of their lungs, smashing and clashing with blood. For some young people and even minors in Hong Kong who are not familiar with the world, following them is as exciting as chasing stars.
Hidden behind these violent "vanguards" are another series of criminal names: Jimmy Lai, Martin Lee, Anson Chan, Albert Ho, known as the "Gang of Four who are treasonous and disruptive of Hong Kong", as well as other leading figures in the opposition camp. .
These behind-the-scenes manipulators collude with external forces and strive to set Huang Zhifeng and his like as role models, and through them, they instill concepts such as "violating the law to uphold justice" and "civil disobedience" to Hong Kong's youth. They are hyping up some social phenomena and social conflicts, causing dissatisfaction among young people, inducing them to go crazy for speculation, and misleading them into thinking that they are engaged in a "noble" cause and "saving Hong Kong" in an alternative way.
They do everything possible to whitewash and even beautify violence, advocating that "reasonable" people can act recklessly without having to bear legal consequences, and gradually induce young people who are not familiar with the world to form an operational logic of "those who follow me will prosper, and those who go against me will perish." Some young people who have been "brainwashed" by the anti-China and destabilizing forces in Hong Kong have transformed into black-clad thugs who are selfish, narrow-minded, self-isolated and hate society in violent incidents.

title: 幕后金主正被调查！香港“民阵”陷入分崩离析，多个团体宣布退出
translation:
has always been an illegal organization
It is worth noting that the Democratic Front has been an illegal organization since its establishment. Singapore's "Lianhe Zaobao" recently quoted sources as saying that the Democratic Front has not registered with the SAR government and is likely to violate the Societies Ordinance. Some media reviewed the information and found that not only was the Democratic Front not registered, it was not included in the "list of registered or exempted associations or branches" of the Hong Kong Police Force. The Societies Ordinance stipulates that any local society or its branch must apply to the Societies Officer for registration or exemption from registration within one month of its establishment in a specified form; if the "Democratic Front" is convicted, the person in charge may be imprisoned for up to 3 years months. Previously, in July 2018, the SAR government issued an order invoking Article 8 of the Societies Ordinance to prohibit the "Hong Kong National Party" that advocates "Hong Kong independence" from continuing to operate.
"Lianhe Zaobao" also disclosed that NED had funded the "Democratic Front" to hold demonstrations and was investigated by relevant parties in Hong Kong; if true, the "Democratic Front" would be banned for violating Hong Kong's national security law. NED, known internationally as the "Second CIA", is a so-called "NGO" funded by the US government and established in Washington in 1983. The "Democratic Front" claims that it has never received any funding from foreign governments or institutions since its establishment, and "has always relied only on donations from citizens during demonstrations and rallies" for financial operations. But in fact, NED and its affiliated organization "Democratic Institute for International Affairs" (NDI) have always had a close relationship with the Democratic Front. A document published by the American research organization "Long Paul Institute for Peace and Prosperity" revealed that in Hong Kong, "Revised During the incident, NED provided financial support to most of the groups involved in the incident. It not only allocated US$200,000 to NDI, but also directly allocated US$90,000 to the "Hong Kong Human Rights Watch" to fund their organizational activities. A conservative estimate shows that the Hong Kong Human Rights Watch received at least US$1.9 million in activity funds from NED from 1995 to 2013. NED also maintains close ties with organizations such as the Civic Party, Labor Party and Democratic Party in the same way, many of which are major members of the Democratic Front.
The "Taiwan independence" forces are another major behind-the-scenes financial backer of the "Democratic Front". During the "anti-extradition bill amendment" demonstration, Shun Zijie once expressed his high-profile thanks to "Taiwan independence" for their support. The list of thanks included three "Taiwan independence" groups, namely the "Hong Kong Students and Graduates in Taiwan Fugitive Offenders Ordinance Concern Group", "Taiwan Citizens' Front" and "Taiwan Citizens' Front". Taiwan Youth Democratic Association". The "Taiwan independence" force "Foundation Progressive Party" also funded the production of "independence" short films for Cen Zijie and spread them on overseas video websites and social platforms to attack "one country, two systems". In addition, colluding with Hong Kong chaos leader Jimmy Lai is another major channel for the Democratic Front to obtain financial aid.

title: Hong Kong’s Protest Year
Protests in HK hit businesses, freeze traffic
“港独”分子冲击立法会被判非法集结罪成立 延后宣判
translation:
Hong Kong's West Kowloon Court announced on the 11th that Leung Chung-hang, Yau Wai-chen, and three assistants, core figures of the "Hong Kong independence" organization Youth New Deal, were found guilty of illegal assembly for storming the Legislative Council conference room in 2016, and the sentencing was postponed.

On October 12, 2016, Liang Songhang and Yau Wai-chen, who advocated "Hong Kong independence", were suspected of humiliating the country when they were sworn in as members of the Legislative Council. They were refused to administer the oath by the Secretary-General of the Legislative Council, Chen Weian, and were subsequently disqualified as members. On November 2, Liang You and three assistants forcibly entered the Legislative Council chamber without the approval of the Legislative Council Chairman and attempted to take an oath on their own. They then pushed and collided with security guards, causing injuries to six security guards.

According to the Hong Kong online media "Hong Kong 01", Judge Wang Shili said when reading the verdict on the 11th that the five defendants obviously gathered with a common purpose and disrupted the meeting outside the Legislative Council for nearly 20 minutes. They continuously attacked the security guards with their numbers and formation, disrupting the proceedings. Liang Songheng once committed provocative behavior by entering the conference room and injuring the security guard. In response to Liang You's claim that their status as members of the Legislative Council at the time had not been revoked and they had the right to enter the conference room, the judge said that even though they were members of the Legislative Council at the time, this did not become a talisman for their crimes.

Liang You expressed dissatisfaction on the 11th and will decide whether to appeal depending on the outcome of the verdict.

title: 香港“七一”游行声势大跌 梁振英呼吁配合政府
translation:
Yesterday was the 18th anniversary of Hong Kong's return to the motherland. This festival, which should be celebrated by the whole of Hong Kong, has always been disrupted by the so-called "Democracy Parade" in recent years.

This year's "July 1" march, launched by the opposition group "Democratic Front", had the theme of "Building Democratic Hong Kong and Regaining Our City's Future", and also proposed slogans such as "amend the Basic Law" and "kick out the Nominating Committee". However, compared with the scale of last year's claimed 500,000 people, the scale of this year's parade has shrunk significantly. According to the Democratic Front itself, there were 48,000 participants, while professional statisticians concluded that there were "less than 30,000 people." On the same day, groups from all walks of life in Hong Kong held about 180 celebration activities to commemorate the return, attracting a total of 300,000 Hong Kong citizens to participate.

Yesterday was also the first anniversary of Hong Kong's return to the motherland after the proposal for political reform and universal suffrage was rejected, attracting special attention from the international media. "The past year has been a year full of opportunities and challenges," Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying said at the handover commemoration ceremony yesterday: "Hong Kong missed a major opportunity to develop democracy, but during the political reform process, Hong Kong society confirmed Hong Kong's basic constitution The principle of law enforcement confirms the necessity of acting in accordance with the Basic Law and other laws." He called on the society to cooperate with the government to develop the economy and improve people's livelihood.

港媒接到录音曝料，“冲击立法会”给5000港元
translation:
Various places in Hong Kong have been vandalized many times by criminals in the past month. On July 1, another violent person occupied the Legislative Council building and wreaked havoc. Yesterday, Hong Kong's "Ta Kung Pao" quoted a recording, revealing that there were organized instigators behind the "attack on the Legislative Council" incident. At the same time, there were financial sponsors who provided money to "find people to do things." The amount ranged from 500 to 5,000 Hong Kong dollars per person, and the division of labor was clear. Recruitment targets should preferably have "student status."
“Elderly people are not welcome to join”
"Ta Kung Pao" received a recorded conversation yesterday (3rd) from a source, in which a suspected "middleman" introduced the division of labor for attacking the Hong Kong Legislative Council, with a clear price tag. for example:
"Frontline staff" can receive salaries ranging from HK$3,000 to HK$5,000. These people are responsible for besieging the police station and breaking into the front line of the Legislative Council, throwing bricks or eggs at the police and buildings; those who "dig bricks" in the logistics are paid HK$500; there are also "reporters" who are responsible for video recording, and the amount is unknown. The working time of each person is 24 hours.
Sources also revealed that "frontline personnel" will wear uniforms for easy identification, including yellow safety helmets, goggles, and masks. "Recruitment" targets only young people aged 22 to 24, "preferably with student status." These people will be taken to the site by bus. Once, an elderly person got on the bus and was kicked out. He was ridiculed and said, "Elderly people are not welcome to join."

title: Protests in HK hit businesses, freeze traffic
香港警方拘捕16男2女 涉冲击立法会等多项暴力事件
translation:
Suspected of disclosing personal information of police officers online

In addition, Hong Kong police launched an operation on July 2 and 3 to arrest seven men and two women, aged between 16 and 40, on suspicion of "accessing computers with criminal or dishonest intent" and "disclosing unauthorized data". personal data obtained with the user's consent', 'criminal damage', 'threat to destroy or damage property' and 'criminal intimidation' offences.

The Hong Kong police stated that they have recently discovered that the personal information of more than 1,100 police officers and their relatives and friends has been improperly disclosed, and that some people have attacked the police website, incited others to destroy public facilities, and committed criminal intimidation. After in-depth investigation by the Cyber ​​Security and Technology Crime Bureau, the operation is still ongoing and more arrests cannot be ruled out.

The Hong Kong police strongly condemned the crime and reiterated that the world of the Internet is not a virtual world with no law to rely on. According to Hong Kong's current laws, most of the laws used to prevent crimes in the real world are applicable to the Internet world. The case is under further follow-up.

惊讶！BBC抢先报道乱港组织解散，把“称XXXXX”发出来了！
translation:
Hong Kong opposition groups have been disbanded in recent days. Recently, Hong Kong media reported that the Hong Kong chaos organization "Civil Human Rights Front (Civil Front)" is also expected to discuss a decision to disband within this week. However, the "Civil Front" has not yet announced a decision. The British Broadcasting Corporation The (BBC) Chinese news website was the first to report that "the Hong Kong Democratic Front announced its dissolution" this afternoon (13th), but it turned out to be an own mistake. Soon, the article was deleted.
The BBC reported under the title "The Hong Kong Democratic Front announced the disbandment of the 'July 1st' parade, and the long-term organizer failed to face the threat of investigation under the National Security Law". At the end of May this year, the "Democratic Front" was sentenced for his involvement in the 2019 demonstration case. Since March this year, the Democratic Front has been accused of receiving funding from official U.S. organizations with the intention of endangering the Chinese Communist Party’s regime, violating Hong Kong’s national security law, and being suspected of other criminal offenses. The pro-establishment faction urges the Hong Kong police to investigate Investigate.

After the Hong Kong Educational Professionals Association (TEA) announced its dissolution on August 10, local media reported that the Democratic Front would also disband. The media stated in the report that after the Democratic Front held a meeting on Friday (13th), it officially announced the relevant decision. However, the article did not give the specific content of the announcement by the Democratic Front, but used "xxxxxx" replace.
In fact, before the BBC issued this report, the Democratic Front had not released any news about its dissolution. However, the relevant BBC report seemed to be a pre-prepared manuscript released in advance. The words "called xxxxxx" could be seen in the text, which seemed to This is the relevant statement of the Democratic Front that will be added.

When the reporter refreshes the page, the words "Page cannot be found (page cannot be found)" are displayed.

title: Chinese people will not be intimidated by any threats
最新铁证！美国在香港搞“政治731”实验，上千大学生成“小白鼠”
translation:
The West's interference in Hong Kong affairs and inciting violent subversion of the "color revolution" has added new evidence of crime.
What is even more unbelievable is the way in which the relevant forces announced and showed off these incriminating evidences.
The latest June issue of the "American Economic Review", a world-renowned academic journal sponsored by the American Economic Association, published an article co-written by scholars from famous universities including the University of Chicago, Harvard University, University of California, Berkeley, University of Munich, and Hong Kong University of Science and Technology. ’s paper examines how to “energize” protest movements in Hong Kong.
Starting in 2017, these so-called "scholars" funded students from the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology to participate in the "July 1st" parade in Hong Kong, euphemistically calling it a "social experiment." The process and results of these students' participation in the gang violence, disrupting and undermining Hong Kong's stability were then openly published in academic journals as "academic results."
To use an analogy that may not be appropriate, I smell the "academic" smell of "731" and Nazi experiments.

title: John Lee Is Hong Kong's New Leader. Here's What to Know | TIME
Hong Kong protests live updates: Protesters storm parliament on anniversary of return to China  - The Washington Post
Six Months of Hong Kong Protests. How Did We Get Here? - The New York Times
Protests in HK hit businesses, freeze traffic
香港之乱丨侮辱国旗、冲击立法会……暴力示威让东方之珠蒙尘
translation:
In order to force the SAR government to meet their demands, radicals have besieged several major SAR government buildings since June 21, 2019.
July 1, 2019, marks the 22nd anniversary of Hong Kong's return to the motherland. The demonstrations, which lasted for three weeks, reached their climax. They occupied the traffic arteries in Central and rushed to the Hong Kong Legislative Council.

The glass exterior wall of the Legislative Council Building could no longer withstand the impact of the metal box trucks again and again.
The demonstrators were well organized and had a clear division of labor: some acted as "attackers" in the front row, while others were responsible for "setting up defenses" to intercept the police. There are also people who act as communicators, using various social tools and gestures to convey the police’s location information. They stacked high iron fences and pushed towards the police line of defense, throwing umbrellas, water bottles, iron sticks and other hard objects at the police, as well as toxic chemical powders and corrosive liquids. Some even tried to snatch the police officers' guns.

There was a huge disparity between the number of police and demonstrators in the building. In order to avoid serious casualties caused by a stampede, the police decided to temporarily evacuate. Activists took over the entire building and targeted electronic screens, projectors, ceilings, lights, alarm clocks, CCTVs, photocopiers, lockers, etc.
In the chamber, radicals announced that they would establish a so-called "provisional government" and openly tore up the Basic Law and defaced the Hong Kong SAR regional emblem on the solemn podium of the Legislative Council.

The dragon and lion flag was the flag used in Hong Kong during the British colonial period. They were brought into the Legislative Council and displayed openly in the center of the chamber.

In the dark of night, the buildings were deserted and a mess, and everything that was usually orderly no longer existed.
Former Hong Kong Criminal Prosecution Commissioner Jiang Lexi: Obviously, this should be strongly condemned. No country or region in a civilized society can allow its own parliament to be violated in this way.

However, similar incidents have repeated themselves in many places in Hong Kong.

香港“35+”非法初选案45人罪成，李家超发声
translation:
Secretary for Security Tang Bingqiang also said on the 30th that during the past 118 days of interrogation, it was clear to everyone that the purpose of these people was not to serve Hong Kong as members of the parliament after running for election, but to paralyze the government. This will inevitably lead to political instability in Hong Kong, leading to a constitutional crisis in Hong Kong and the shutdown of the SAR government, which will impact and greatly damage society, the economy, and people's livelihood. This damage is catastrophic.
Tang Bingqiang criticized them for planning to bring society to a standstill through large-scale street riots and other means, in order to achieve personal political goals and ignore the life and death of Hong Kong citizens. What they did was basically betraying Hong Kong people, which was extremely ugly, ugly and vicious. They used illegal means to seriously interfere with, obstruct and undermine the Hong Kong SAR government's performance of its duties and functions in accordance with the law.
Deng Bingqiang also emphasized that it was seen from the interrogation that anyone who wants to endanger national security will not escape justice. The "Maintenance of National Security Ordinance" has come into effect, making the SAR more capable of safeguarding national security. However, we cannot take it lightly. External forces and their agents in Hong Kong are always watching and want to endanger our security. Throughout the trial, external forces continued to smear the judiciary, the Department of Justice, and law enforcement agencies, and also called for "sanctions" on those who performed their duties in an attempt to interfere with the independent trial and influence the court's decision.
Chief Superintendent of the National Security Department of the Hong Kong Police, Li Guihua, said on the 30th that the defendants had different levels of participation and roles, and they were lawless and defied the law. This time the court convicted them beyond reasonable doubt. The stern verdict was a wake-up call for them, letting them know that what they did at that time was wrong and illegal.
He pointed out that today, more than three years later, Hong Kong is relatively calm. But if we had not made a decisive decision at that time and completely pulled out these people, Hong Kong might have embarked on what they said at the time was the "Ten Steps to Speculation". As a result, there would continue to be many demonstrations and society would continue to come to a standstill. "Let me ask everyone if they want to have this kind of life." ?”
In addition, in response to some Western countries making irresponsible remarks on the results of this ruling, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said on the 30th that Hong Kong is a society governed by the rule of law. It is a basic principle that laws must be followed and violations must be investigated. No one can pretend to be "democracy". "engage in illegal activities and attempt to escape legal sanctions.
Mao Ning said that the central government firmly supports the Hong Kong SAR's law enforcement and judicial agencies in fulfilling their duties in accordance with the law and punishing various behaviors that endanger national security. It firmly opposes individual countries using relevant judicial cases to interfere in China's internal affairs, smear and undermine the rule of law in Hong Kong.

title: 今年“七一”香港发生重大变化，令西方媒体哀嚎不已
translation:
In addition, Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po and other media also revealed that the organizers of this parade also violated the parade route prescribed by the police. Fortunately, the police worked hard to maintain order and did not cause chaos.
What’s ridiculous is that even the Western media knows that the demonstration has become less and less popular in Hong Kong, but their stance of “revolting against China” determines that they will still use this parade to complete their “demonization” this year. China" topic composition.
For example, Reuters, BBC, Deutsche Welle, and the New York Times all clearly expressed in their reports that "even though the number of people this year is the smallest, it is still exciting." They also "stealthfully changed the concept" and described the extremists who undermined Hong Kong's rule of law and social order as "democrats", while the Hong Kong government and the central government became the "villains" described by these Western media.
Among them, the BBC also specifically posted a photo of Hong Kong independence activist Joshua Wong in its report and called him a "democrat", while the New York Times highlighted in its report that "the British period was the best period for Hong Kong." "Such remarks.
Of course, in Geng's view, the tone of these Western media reports is more like venting a feeling of embarrassment and anger. Moreover, I watched the New York Times and other Western media scold US President Trump as "xenophobic" every day in the United States, while at the same time giving the "xenophobic" anti-Mainland and Hong Kong independence forces in Hong Kong those in Hong Kong calling mainlanders "China" and "locusts" The platform will give people a feeling of "schizophrenia"...
Therefore, I think we mainland people don’t need to take these reports and this demonstration too seriously, just treat it as a joke.

社评：搞“七一大游行”不符合香港利益
translation:
Hong Kong and the Mainland have one country, two systems. It is difficult for the two societies to understand each other 100%, but one basic truth should be clear, that is, it will never be beneficial to engage in sharp political confrontation. It will be harmful to individuals, a certain unit, and the entire country. Harmful.

The most radical people are instilling in people that through extreme confrontation, Hong Kong society can maximize its interests. This is a dangerous advocacy that uses the interests of Hong Kong society and the country as a whole to support their personal political ambitions. Hong Kong simply does not have the conditions for the political confrontation they are deceiving, but a small number of people in Hong Kong have become obsessed with politics. At first glance, they appear to be "civilized and rational", but in fact they are full of paranoia. Their political fanaticism is close to that of society. The boiling point of jet destructive power.

Nowadays, some extremists are calling on the Internet to support "Occupy Central", and the mainland should also "Occupy Shenzhen" or even "Occupy Tiananmen". There is no evidence that such calls are made by Hong Kong "Occupy Central" people, but Hong Kong citizens should pay attention You can see how some extreme forces hope to use "Occupy Central" to disrupt the entire country. Of course, this is an impossible fantasy for them.

People who hope that Hong Kong and the country will be well should do their best to help Hong Kong form a healthy political ecology. There is no need for one's own participation to help extremists build "trenches" and help them create the impression that "Hong Kong public opinion is against the central government." That is not what Hong Kong needs. It will not bring "democracy" to Hong Kong, but will only destroy the social foundation for Hong Kong's practice of democracy.

People on the mainland are happy to see Hong Kong maintain a different political system from the mainland so that one country, two systems can be truly implemented. No one wants to see the "mainlandization" of Hong Kong, and it is even less likely to be the policy direction of the central government. Extremists claim that the central government wants to attack Hong Kong's freedom of speech and prevent Hong Kong's democracy. Only through "resistance" can Hong Kong's future be defended. This is deception. Don't be fooled by them.

title: 香港七一游行500余名被捕者悉数获释，有人身藏攻击性武器
translation:
The overseas edition of People's Daily published an article today criticizing the July 1st demonstrations in Hong Kong. According to reports, Hong Kong's radical opposition organizations "Scholar Citizen Thought" and the Federation of Students rehearsed "Occupy Central" on the evening of July 1, illegally trying to force the Hong Kong SAR government to accept "citizen nominations" that were not in compliance with the Basic Law. People from all walks of life in Hong Kong pointed out that the opposition first used the illegal "referendum" to build momentum, and then illegally "Occupy Central". They were kidnapping public opinion in order to challenge "one country, two systems", ignore the mainstream public opinion in Hong Kong society, and harm the interests of Hong Kong's 7 million citizens.

Famous person: "Don't do anything illegal"

The report also interviewed many Hong Kong people to express their views on the matter. Chen Yongqi, a member of the Standing Committee of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, told the People's Daily that he was young and opposed many things, but no one should do anything illegal. The so-called "referendum" launched by the "Occupy Central" group a few days ago "can't see the actual number of people voting and whether the votes are duplicated, so there must be something wrong."

Cheng Yaotang, executive chairman of the Hong Kong Celebration Committee, told the People's Daily that the most important thing for citizens to express their demands is to abide by the law, and instigating violations of the law and causing trouble are not Hong Kong's core values. Tam Yiu-chung, chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of China and member of the Legislative Council, pointed out that the voices from all walks of life against "Occupy Central" are very loud, and he does not understand why the opposition still goes against public opinion. "Occupy Central" is blatantly illegal. It not only blocks traffic, but also affects people's daily lives and poses a danger to people's lives and property. He was worried that the situation would eventually get out of control, and urged the opposition to think carefully and "illegal things should not be done." Ip Kwok-him, convener of the DAB Legislative Council caucus, pointed out that everyone, including students, should not engage in illegal and violent behaviors. The police should act in accordance with the law.

title: 香港七一游行：今年有什么特殊的地方？
translation: This year's July 1st Hong Kong Parade, the Hong Kong Police Force estimated that 98,600 people participated - based on this number, this parade was the largest public parade and protest since 2003. What’s new about this year’s parade? How can young people get involved? How do different discourse systems describe their positions? One detail is quite interesting: Although there are many demonstrators who are concerned about political reform, and the opposition calls this year's parade the "strongest political hurricane" since Hong Kong's return to the motherland, Hong Kong media have emphasized that the people participating in the parade are diverse. Although the parade The momentum is not small, but it is not all for political reform, but a "hodgepodge".

title: Protesters in Hong Kong Have Changed Their Playbook. Here’s How. - The New York Times
香港示威者冲击政府总部及立法会，投掷汽油弹
translation:
According to CCTV News, on the afternoon of August 31, a large number of demonstrators stormed the government headquarters and the Legislative Council and threw petrol bombs. The police repeatedly warned the demonstrators to stop illegal activities, but to no avail. The riot police fired tear gas and used minimum force to disperse the demonstrators.
In addition, some demonstrators also threw petrol bombs at the police headquarters. The police severely condemned all violent acts by the demonstrators.
Police warned demonstrators to stop violating the law and leave immediately.
According to Global Network, around 18:00, anti-riot water cannon trucks were dispatched near the Admiralty Government Headquarters to disperse violent demonstrators. According to live video, the water cannon truck not only fired "white water cannons" that day, but also fired "blue water cannons."

幕后金主正被调查！香港“民阵”陷入分崩离析，多个团体宣布退出
translation:
Members "jumped ship" one after another
According to a report by Hong Kong's "Oriental Daily" on the 14th, the "ADPL" issued a statement on the evening of the 13th saying that based on the current political atmosphere and situation, it would no longer participate in the work of the "Democratic Front". Previously, organizations such as the "Neighborhood and Workers Service Office", the Civic Party, the "New Democratic Alliance" and the "Catholic Justice and Peace Committee" have publicly stated that they will no longer participate in the meetings and work of the "Democratic Front". Lai Renbiao, vice chairman of the Kuomintang Party, said that the Kuomintang party is currently suffering heavy losses and many party members are in prison. "The Kuomintang party needs to face reality and risks and has the responsibility to protect party members." He said that the "Democratic Front" has organized Hong Kong-wide demonstrations for many years, and the Civic Party has actively participated. However, due to the implementation of Hong Kong's national security law and the epidemic, it is no longer possible for the "Democratic Front" to hold relevant activities, and many demonstrations will It was classified as an illegal activity and went against the purpose of the "Democratic Front" to hold legal demonstrations. On the 14th, the "Education Association" announced that taking into account the recent political situation, it decided to terminate its participation in the work and meetings of the "Democratic Front", effective immediately. The Democratic Party is also discussing whether to withdraw or no longer participate in the "Democratic Front" activities. It is expected that a decision will be made on the 15th.
Chen Haohuan, the convener of the Democratic Front, admitted that six or seven groups had withdrawn. However, according to a report by "Sing Tao Daily" on the 14th, an unnamed person from the "Democratic Front" secretariat said that in addition to the disbanded "Democracy Dynamics", the "Chinese Democratic College" that plans to withdraw from Hong Kong, and the public statement of withdrawal In addition to the Civic Party and other organizations, 15 other institutions and organizations have actually withdrawn from the Democratic Front, including the Christian Student Movement, the Hong Kong Democratic Development Network and the Chinese University Student Union. "If the news is true, the Democratic Front 43 Among member organizations, 21 organizations will withdraw." Chen Manqi, founding president of the Chinese Lawyers Association of Hong Kong, analyzed that the leaders of the "speculators" faction realized that the past actions of the "Democratic Front" were likely to be illegal, so they "jumped ship" one after another, and based on "patriots governing Hong Kong" In principle, the SAR government should proactively follow up on the incident.

title: Hong Kong protests: All the latest updates | Hong Kong Protests News | Al Jazeera
Commentary: Call Hong Kong police who they are: heroes of Hong Kong
Hong Kong: One year after China passed the national security law, residents feel Beijing’s tightening grip | CNN
维修费达6000万！香港警方将拘捕冲击立法会暴徒
translation:
Demonstrators opposing the "Fugitive Offenders Ordinance" stormed the Hong Kong Legislative Council building on the evening of July 1, causing extremely serious damage. The repair cost is expected to be as high as 60 million Hong Kong dollars (approximately RMB 52.98 million). The Hong Kong police have collected evidence and will arrest the extremists in accordance with the law.
Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region said that violent acts will be "pursued to the end". Legal sources said that the rioters who attacked the Legislative Council committed multiple crimes and could be sentenced to a maximum sentence of 14 years.

Xinhua Headlines: Hong Kong people express support for police, calling for end to violence
Interview: Hong Kong MTR under strain amid prolonged violence, says CEO
香港示威者冲击立法会大楼，外交部、中联办、港澳办都发声了
translation:
In response to the brutal interference of relevant countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom in Hong Kong affairs, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Geng Shuang pointed out at a regular press conference today (July 2) that seemingly fair advocacy of the right to peaceful protest and calls to avoid violence are completely inappropriate. A naked double standard, extremely hypocritical and ugly!
Geng Shuang asked at the press conference, "If the violent attack on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong happened in the United States or Europe, how would they handle it? Will they let it go? Everyone has seen on TV how the police in the United States and Europe treated it. How do they enforce the law when the same thing happens in Hong Kong? Not only do they not object to condemning it, but they also make irresponsible remarks. "
Discussing the nature of the violent incidents, Geng Shuang said at the press conference that the violent attacks on the Legislative Council building and wanton damage to Legislative Council facilities in the Hong Kong SAR are serious violations that trample on the rule of law and endanger social order. We strongly condemn this, and the central government firmly supports the Hong Kong SAR government and police in handling the incident in accordance with the law.
"I would like to reiterate here that Hong Kong is a special administrative region of China and Hong Kong affairs are purely China's internal affairs. We express strong dissatisfaction and firm opposition to relevant countries' gross interference in Hong Kong affairs and China's internal affairs." Geng Shuang said that we once again warn relevant countries to be cautious Be careful in your words and deeds. Do not interfere in Hong Kong's internal affairs in any way, do not embolden violent lawbreakers in any form, do not send any misleading signals, and do not make any wrong moves.

title: 香港愤慨立法会遭冲击 港媒称下一站是旺角
translation:
Demonstrators stormed the Legislative Council several times

"A society governed by the rule of law does not allow the expression of any demands through violence." "If there is sufficient evidence and legal permission, (the police and the Department of Justice) will strictly enforce the law and do not want the public to think that they can get away with committing illegal acts." Hong Kong on the 19th. Secretary for Justice Yuen Kwok-keung condemned the violence that occurred at the Legislative Council building in the early morning. The Hong Kong government even condemned "thug behavior" in a statement, saying that Hong Kong citizens must abide by the law when expressing their opinions or demands and "violence will never be tolerated."

"Taiwan's Sunflower Student Movement also attacked the Legislative Yuan, why can't Hong Kong people attack?" Hong Kong's "Ming Pao" said that on the night of the 18th, dozens of demonstrators wearing masks began to attack the Hong Kong Legislative Council building shouting such slogans. The incident described by the newspaper was roughly as follows: At about 10 o'clock that night, a group of demonstrators who called themselves "netizens" gathered in the demonstration area near the Legislative Council, and then tried to break into the Legislative Council for the first time, but failed. Legislative Council security immediately blocked all exits of the Legislative Council. The attackers claimed that the purpose of the operation was to prevent parliamentarians from entering and exiting normally, in response to the court's injunction order to clear the CITIC Building in Admiralty during the day. At 11:04 in the night, the demonstrators launched a second wave of attacks. This time they claimed that the purpose of the action was to prevent the Legislative Council from reviewing the Internet copyright-related legislation they called "Internet 23" on the 19th. However, this round of attacks was lighter. At 11:40 in the evening, a group of "netizens" wearing masks tried to rush to the main podium in the Admiralty occupied area, calling on everyone to storm the Legislative Council, and had an argument with the "Occupy Central" picket team. At about 1 a.m., dozens of demonstrators stormed the Legislative Council with iron horses and bricks. Some shouted "Come on!" and some shouted "Hurry up! There is no time!" After the glass door of the Legislative Council was smashed, one person The demonstrators rushed into the building, but the people watching and shouting outside did not follow, and the "lone intruder" immediately evacuated. The police who arrived to stop the protest used pepper spray to disperse the demonstrators. According to the Hong Kong government's announcement on the 19th, the police used minimum force to prevent the attack, arrested a total of 6 people, and injured 3 police officers. Hong Kong's "Bus Daily" said the arrested persons were aged between 18 and 24 years old.

title: Hong Kong protests: All the latest updates | Hong Kong Protests News | Al Jazeera
Hong Kong protesters storm legislature – DW – 07/01/2019
香港愤慨立法会遭冲击 港媒称下一站是旺角
translation:
"Thug behavior!" On the 19th, Hong Kong Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong member IP Kwok-him (pro-establishment camp) fiercely condemned the demonstrators for preventing the normal operation of the Legislative Council and "impacting the core values ​​of Hong Kong." The South China Morning Post stated that on this day, in addition to the Hong Kong government's "strongest condemnation" of the attack, members of both the pro-establishment and pan-democratic factions also condemned it in unison. Pan-democratic lawmaker Zhang Chaoxiong was at the scene to block the attack on the night of the 18th, but was pulled away. He criticized the impact incident on the 19th for "casting a stain on the 'Umbrella Movement' and giving others the opportunity to discredit the 'Umbrella Movement'." Democratic Party Chairwoman Emily Lau also criticized the attack, saying the attackers had "nothing to do with us." Chairman of the Hong Kong Legislative Council Tsang Yu said that anyone who obstructs members from participating in meetings is a criminal offence.

Hong Kong's "Sing Tao Daily" stated that the "Occupy Central Three" also issued a statement on the 19th, strongly condemning the masked demonstrators' attack on the Legislative Council building. Call on supporters to adhere to the principle of "non-violence" and not give the government an excuse to violently clear the area. On the same day, Joshua Wong, the convener of "Scholar-Mind Thought" and Zhou Yongkang, secretary-general of the Federation of Students, both said they had no prior knowledge of the attack. The latter said that the Internet Copyright Amendment Ordinance will not be voted on until the middle of next year, and they do not understand why the attackers are eager to take action. However, although the action methods and coordination are not satisfactory, the government should also review and reflect. Joshua Wong said that the activists also support "real universal suffrage", so there is no need to use the word "condemn". Hong Kong's "Wen Wei Po" stated that Huang Zhifeng was at the scene of the attack in the early morning of the 19th. He also shouted through a loudspeaker that the police could not enforce the law in the Legislative Council and asked the demonstrators to take photos of the police enforcement as evidence.

Xinhua Headlines: How external forces have inflamed tensions in Hong Kong
香港警方拘捕8人涉嫌7月1日等非法游行
translation:
[Hong Kong police arrested 8 people on suspicion of illegal demonstrations on July 1st and other illegal demonstrations] Hong Kong police introduced on the 8th that the Criminal Division of the Hong Kong Island Region took action that day and arrested a total of 8 men in multiple districts across Hong Kong. The arrested persons are suspected of illegal demonstrations on July 1 and are currently being detained for investigation.

According to multiple Hong Kong media reports, the eight men arrested include former opposition legislators Wu Zhiwei and Zhu Kaidi, opposition district councilors Chen Rongtai, Xu Zijian, and Tsang Kin-cheng, opposition political group Social Democratic League Vice Chairman Leung Kwok-hung, and member Deng Shili , Chen Haohuan, convener of the opposition platform "Civil Human Rights Front".

The Hong Kong police stated that they noticed that someone was outside the Court of Final Appeal on June 30 this year and incited others to participate in an unauthorized assembly they planned to hold on Hong Kong Island the next day. Later, on July 1, some of the above-mentioned persons, together with other persons related to the case, organized and led a procession to conduct an unauthorized assembly in the Wan Chai area.

The police said that after in-depth investigation and consultation with the SAR Government's Department of Justice for legal advice, the Criminal Division of the Hong Kong Island Region took action on the 8th and arrested eight men, aged between 24 and 64 years old. The arrested persons are suspected of violating the Public Order Ordinance, Chapter 245 of the Laws of Hong Kong, on charges of "inciting others to knowingly participate in unauthorized assemblies", "holding or organizing unauthorized assemblies" and "knowingly participating in unauthorized assemblies". Withheld for investigation.

According to Hong Kong's Public Order Ordinance, the crime of illegal assembly is punishable by up to 5 years in prison.

title: 乱港分子制定“三条战线”妄想七一决战？乱港四人帮各怀啥心思？
translation:
On June 28, the 20th session of the Standing Committee of the 13th National People's Congress held its first plenary meeting at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. The meeting continued to review the draft law on safeguarding national security in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and other laws.
It is reported that the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress has reached a general consensus on the content of the draft national security legislation related to Hong Kong, and there is no suspense that it will be voted on during the session!
Under such a good situation, Hong Kong people also want to "join in the fun": The reasons for the chaos in Hong Kong, which have been suppressed for a long time, have been secretly negotiated and planned to "make trouble" on July 1, and they have three "three points" that sound very bluffing. "Front" fully promotes the "Decisive Battle"!

title: 香港警方再拘4人 冲击立法会暴力分子大起底
translation:
The Hong Kong Legislative Council was attacked in the early morning of the 19th, resulting in the most serious violent incident in the "occupied area" of Admiralty since the "Occupy Central" movement. Hong Kong public opinion revealed the identities of some of the thugs yesterday. Observer.com cited reports on the same day, saying that those who stormed the Legislative Council were suspected to be from the extremist organization "Hot-Blooded Citizens". The leader was suspected to be the host of "Hot-Blooded Times" and was nicknamed "The Frenchman". The attack also triggered internal strife among the "Occupy Central" activists. .

Yesterday, the Hong Kong police detained four more people, bringing the number of people detained after the attack on the Legislative Council to 10. Among those arrested were close comrades of the pan-democrats and young people in the sixth form.

title: AP PHOTOS: The rise and fall of Hong Kong's July 1 protests | AP News
涉七一非法集会游行，香港警方拘捕乱港分子梁国雄与陈皓桓
translation:
On December 8, Hong Kong police arrested Chen Haohuan, the convener of the "Hong Kong Independence" organization "Democratic Front" at Tai Hing Garden in Tuen Mun, and arrested Hong Kong chaos element and former Legislative Council member "Longhair" Leung Kwok-hung in Kai Yip Estate, Kowloon Bay. According to Hong Kong media reports, two people were arrested on suspicion of illegal assembly and procession on July 1 this year, and the case was handed over to the Criminal Division of the Hong Kong Island Region for follow-up.

According to reports, on the first July 1st Handover Day after the implementation of the National Security Law in Hong Kong this year, groups such as the Democratic Front initiated a march on Hong Kong Island on that day. Although the Hong Kong police refused to issue a "notice of no objection", about 10,000 people mobilized that day. During the demonstrations, a large number of violent demonstrators in Causeway Bay and Wan Chai used debris to block roads, set fires and vandalized shops. Some people waved "Hong Kong independence" flags and American and British flags on the streets, and shouted slogans opposing Hong Kong's national security law and Hong Kong independence. Hong Kong police arrested 370 people, including 6 men and 4 women on suspicion of violating Hong Kong's national security law.

In addition to Leung Kwok-wai and Chan Haohuan, former Hong Kong Democratic Party Chairman Wu Chi-wai, former Legislative Council member Chu Kai-dy, Eastern District Councilors Tsang Kin-shing and Chan Wing-tai later also pointed out through social networking sites that they were arrested by the Hong Kong police in the early morning. Hong Kong social democrats Lien Tang Sai-lai and Eastern District Councilor Tsui Chi-jian were also arrested.

title: 幕后金主正被调查！香港“民阵”陷入分崩离析，多个团体宣布退出
translation:
One of the root causes of riots in Hong Kong
The full name of the "Civil Front for Human Rights" is the "Civil Human Rights Front". It was established in September 2002. It claims to be "a joint platform focusing on political and democratic issues". In fact, it is a "campaign for speculation". Almost all opposition members participate in it. At its peak, more than 60 organizations joined.
The original intention of the establishment of the Democratic Front was to carry out legislative work on Article 23 of the Basic Law. In September 2002, the Hong Kong Security Bureau issued the "Consultation Document on the Implementation of Article 23 of the Basic Law." In 2003, when the SARS epidemic subsided, the Democratic Front launched the "July 1 Parade" to oppose the legislation of Article 23, which caused the SAR government to In March, it was announced that the submission of the second reading of the draft would be postponed indefinitely. Since then, the "Democratic Front" has instigated the "July 1 Parade" every year, with the goal of "one country, two systems" and the administration of the SAR government. From 2004 to 2007, the "Democratic Front" continuously incited citizens to fight for the so-called "double universal suffrage", and the opposition began to use Achieving "double universal suffrage" as the ultimate goal of "resistance to China". In 2012, Yang Zhengxian, the former convener of the Democratic Front, together with Yan Wuzhou, the then vice-president of the Chinese University Student Union, and Joshua Wong, the former secretary-general of Demosisto Hong Kong, launched an "anti-national education" campaign, inciting the academic community to participate in a class strike and forcing the SAR government to The decision to establish a moral and national education department was eventually withdrawn. This has endless consequences for Hong Kong society. It is precisely because some students do not understand the history of mainland China and Hong Kong that they eventually embark on the path of illegal "Occupy Central" and inciting violence.
After the "July 1 Parade" initiated by the "Democratic Front" ended in 2014, its members "Students' Federation" and "Scholar People's Thought" launched a sit-in activity in Central that night to "rehearse Occupy Central", which also became a 79-day long protest. The beginning of the illegal "Occupy Central" campaign. Since then, the Democratic Front has gone further and further down the path of so-called "violent resistance." On June 9, 2019, the first large-scale demonstration that broke out in Hong Kong due to the "anti-extradition bill amendment" was initiated by the "Democratic Front". The demonstration later turned into a riot. Some thugs stormed the Legislative Council building and clashed with the police. Throughout the "rebellion over the amendment bill", the "Democratic Front" has always been a platform for "soliciting speculation" and black violence in Hong Kong. Almost every parade and rally launched has paved the way for black-clad thugs and "Hong Kong independence" elements, which eventually evolved into Massive riots.
After the implementation of the National Security Law in Hong Kong last year, the "Democratic Front" still openly "challenged" and attempted to launch demonstrations and rallies on July 1 and October 1 last year. However, under the shock of the National Security Law, it was ultimately unable to cause trouble. However, this year's New Year's Day demonstration instigated by the Democratic Front once again saw black-clad thugs vandalizing, blocking roads, and setting fires everywhere. Many leaders of the organization were also charged with "conspiracy to subvert state power" for attempting to paralyze the governance of the SAR government. Among them, Au Noxuan served as the convener of the "Democratic Front" from October 2016 to October 2017, and Shun Zijie served as the convener of the Democratic Front in 2015. He served as the convener from October 2016 to October 2016 and from October 2018 to October 2020. Chen Haohuan, who succeeded Shum Zijie as the convener in October last year, once organized illegal gatherings in his "personal capacity" many times after the "Democratic Front" launched a demonstration and was opposed by the police, involving 4 cases and 14 crimes. Some Hong Kong media bluntly stated that facts have repeatedly proven that the "Democratic Front" is not a platform for Hong Kong citizens to express their opinions at all, but an evil political organization that promotes violence. It is not only responsible for the Hong Kong riots, but also creates violent conflicts one after another. One of the root causes of the destruction of the rule of law and social unrest in Hong Kong.

In 2019, there was a turmoil over the amendment bill in Hong Kong. Radical violent crimes seriously trampled on the rule of law and social order, seriously undermined Hong Kong's prosperity and stability, and seriously challenged the bottom line of the "one country, two systems" principle. On July 21, 2019, radicals surrounded and attacked the Liaison Office of the Central People’s Government in Hong Kong. They threw eggs and black paint bombs at the national emblem, and wrote words that insulted the dignity of the country and nation.
In 2019, there was a turmoil over the amendment bill in Hong Kong. Radical violent crimes seriously trampled on the rule of law and social order, seriously undermined Hong Kong's prosperity and stability, and seriously challenged the bottom line of the "one country, two systems" principle.
